title: About Me
text:
I am a Master of Business Analytics student at Monash University, passionate about using data to uncover insights that drive smarter and more informed decisions.
My studies have built a strong foundation in statistics, programming, and data communication, but what excites me most is the power of storytelling through analytics and visualisation.
Iâ€™m fascinated by how data appears in every part of life â€” from business and technology to sports and even cooking. Whether the dataset is small or enormous, data always offers a different lens to understand the world, uncover patterns, and challenge assumptions.
This website is my space to share projects, reflect on what Iâ€™m learning, and explore how analytics can turn everyday questions into meaningful insights. I see data not just as numbers, but as a way to connect ideas across disciplines and make sense of complexity.

Developing high-quality, publication-ready reports using R and Quarto with strong documentation and cross-referencing

Enhancing my ability to translate analytical findings into strategic business insights

This site showcases selected coursework and mini-projects from my analytics journey at Monash University. Itâ€™s an evolving space where I continue to refine my writing, visualisation style, and coding practices as I grow as an analyst.

title: About Me
text:
Capturing the Details
Unlike weekly or monthly manual sampling, these sensors record water-quality data in real time. This means scientists can see short-term spikes and fluctuations that often go unnoticed.
The study measured nitrate along with conductivity, turbidity, dissolved oxygen, and water temperature. Elevation and flow were also included to understand broader environmental influences.

title: About Me
text:
Key Findings

Consistent Drivers: Across all sites, just a handful of variablesâ€”conductivity, turbidity, dissolved oxygen, water temperature, and elevationâ€”explained nearly all nitrate variation.
Rapid Fluctuations: Sensors captured sudden nitrate spikes during rainfall or runoff events, revealing dynamics invisible to traditional sampling.
Site Differences Matter: While the overall framework worked at all streams, local calibration was important. Each site had unique interactions between variables and nitrate.

Takeaway: By focusing on a few core water-quality indicators, monitoring programs can gain reliable insights without being overwhelmed by unnecessary data.

title: About Me
text:
Implications for Water Management
High-frequency sensors provide a powerful tool for managers and environmental agencies. They allow for:

More responsive water-quality monitoring
Early detection of pollution events
Targeted interventions to reduce nutrient loads

However, the study also highlights the importance of careful data management and site-specific calibration. Technology is only part of the solutionâ€”smart implementation matters.

title: About Me
text:
Conclusion
High-frequency monitoring doesnâ€™t just improve our understanding of streamsâ€”it helps protect them. By identifying the key drivers of nitrate, this research equips managers with actionable insights to safeguard freshwater ecosystems from nutrient pollution.

title: High-Frequency Sensors Reveal What Drives Nitrate in Our Streams
text:
Freshwater ecosystems are under pressure from excess nutrients, particularly nitrate, which fuels algal blooms and degrades water quality. Understanding what drives nitrate concentrations is key to protecting these vital systemsâ€”but traditional water monitoring often misses the nuances.
A recent study explored this problem using high-frequency sensor data from three U.S. streams:

Arikaree River, Colorado: a semi-arid, agricultural river
Caribouâ€“Poker Creeks, Alaska: a subarctic, largely undisturbed stream
Lewis Run, Virginia: a temperate river affected by agriculture and urbanisation



Unlike weekly or monthly manual sampling, these sensors record water-quality data in real time. This means scientists can see short-term spikes and fluctuations that often go unnoticed.
The study measured nitrate along with conductivity, turbidity, dissolved oxygen, and water temperature. Elevation and flow were also included to understand broader environmental influences.



Figure ?@fig-nitrate shows the temporal variation of nitrate at the three streams.

# Include the nitrate timeseries figure
knitr::include_graphics("nitrate_timeseries.png")












library(knitr)

# Create data frame for stream sites
sites_summary <- data.frame(
  `Stream Name` = c("Arikaree River", "Caribouâ€“Poker Creeks", "Lewis Run"),
  Location = c("Colorado", "Alaska", "Virginia"),
  `Monitoring Period` = c("2017â€“2019", "2017â€“2019", "2017â€“2019"),
  `Sensors / Variables Measured` = c(
    "Nitrate, Conductivity, Turbidity, DO, Temp",
    "Nitrate, Conductivity, Turbidity, DO, Temp",
    "Nitrate, Conductivity, Turbidity, DO, Temp"
  )
)

# Display table
kable(
  sites_summary,
  caption = "Overview of stream sites, monitoring period, and measured variables.",
  align = "lccc"
)

The three streams studied vary in climate and land use Table ?@tbl-sites_summary, which allows us to test whether a common modelling framework can capture nitrate variation across different conditions.




Consistent Drivers: Across all sites, just a handful of variablesâ€”conductivity, turbidity, dissolved oxygen, water temperature, and elevationâ€”explained nearly all nitrate variation.
Rapid Fluctuations: Sensors captured sudden nitrate spikes during rainfall or runoff events, revealing dynamics invisible to traditional sampling.
Site Differences Matter: While the overall framework worked at all streams, local calibration was important. Each site had unique interactions between variables and nitrate.

Takeaway: By focusing on a few core water-quality indicators, monitoring programs can gain reliable insights without being overwhelmed by unnecessary data.



High-frequency sensors provide a powerful tool for managers and environmental agencies. They allow for:

More responsive water-quality monitoring
Early detection of pollution events
Targeted interventions to reduce nutrient loads

However, the study also highlights the importance of careful data management and site-specific calibration. Technology is only part of the solutionâ€”smart implementation matters.



High-frequency monitoring doesnâ€™t just improve our understanding of streamsâ€”it helps protect them. By identifying the key drivers of nitrate, this research equips managers with actionable insights to safeguard freshwater ecosystems from nutrient pollution.



Kermorvant, C., Smith, J., & Brown, L. (2023). Understanding links between water-quality variables and nitrate concentration in freshwater streams using high-frequency sensor data. Environmental Monitoring Journal, 15(3), 145â€“160. https://cwd.numbat.space/assignments/assignment-2-papers/Kermorvant2023.pdf
